QuestionText: How might climate change influence the burden of disease in Central Asian nations over the next 20 to 30 years?
ResponseText:
### Question  
How might climate change influence the burden of disease in Central Asian nations over the next 20 to 30 years?

### Short answer (1-line)  
Over the next 20–30 years, climate change will increase the burden of vector-, water-, and heat-related diseases in Central Asia through hotter, longer summers and intensified extreme weather, most notably in and around Tashkent.

### Executive summary (≤ 120 words)  
Tashkent and broader Central Asia are projected to experience hotter, longer summers (summer temperatures rising by 1.1–1.9°C), an increase in extreme heat days (annual days ≥35°C climbing from 41.6 to 66.7 by 2050), and shifting rainfall extremes. Higher temperatures and altered precipitation will expand the range and seasonality of disease-carrying vectors (mosquitoes, ticks), escalating risks of malaria, dengue, and tick-borne illnesses. Water-borne diseases and heat stress will also rise, particularly impacting vulnerable urban populations. Without adaptation, disease incidence and health-system strain will worsen; cross-sector surveillance and heat-health action plans are critical to mitigate these growing climatic risks.

### Evidence & sources *(supports credibility)*  
| # | Statement | Evidence supporting the statement | Source | Type | 
|---|-----------|-----------------------------------|--------|------|
| 1 | Extreme heat days will sharply rise | Days over 35°C increase from 41.6 (historic) to 66.7 (2040–2050) annually | XCLIM_AI (CMIP6 HighResMIP multi-model ensemble) | Numeric |
| 2 | Summer mean temperatures will rise significantly | June–August means increase by 1.1–1.9°C by 2040–2049 | Atmospheric model simulations for Tashkent; XCLIM_AI | Numeric |
| 3 | Vector-borne disease risk is strongly tied to higher temperatures | Regional/global literature links warmer, longer warm seasons to expanded mosquito and tick habitat and infection season | Wikipedia RAG_search; Climate-disease reviews | Citation/Text |
| 4 | Water- and heat-related illnesses will escalate | Combined heat stress and hydrological extremes amplify risk for water-borne disease and heat stress, especially in cities | Wikipedia; XCLIM_AI | Text |
| 5 | Climate projections detail local seasonality shifts | Tashkent monthly data: August mean temperature up to 36.06°C and near-zero summer rainfall by 2040s | Provided model output | Numeric |

### Key uncertainties & assumptions  
- Scenario / model range: Based on high emissions (CMIP6 SSP5-8.5), with actual risks depending on global/region-wide mitigation and adaptation.
- Data limitations: Lacks localized epidemiological trend data and detail on health system response capacities.
- Confidence statements: High confidence in heating/extreme event projections; moderate confidence for specific disease increases due to adaptive factors.

### Recommendations *(supports actionability)*  
1. Expand heat-health action plans and public early warning systems ahead of and during extreme summer events, with special focus on children, elderly, and outdoor workers.
2. Enhance vector surveillance and integrated climate-health monitoring, including cooperation between health, meteorological, and urban planning sectors to adapt water supply, sanitation, and disease control strategies.

### Accessibility notes  
- “Vector-borne”: Diseases that are spread by animals such as mosquitoes or ticks.
- “CMIP6 HighResMIP”: A set of international climate models used to predict future temperature and precipitation changes under scenarios of greenhouse gas emissions.
